  • mlcf.datatools.data_intervals module

mlcf.datatools.data_intervals moduleÔÉÅ

Data Interval Module.

It is a data structure that divides the input data into n intervals and then into 3 sets such as the train set, the validation set and the test set. It provides DataIntervals class allowing us to handle the Nx3 intervals data structure.

Example:

from mlcf.datatools.data_intervals import DataIntervals
from mlcf.datatools.standardize_fct import ClassicStd, MinMaxStd
from mlcf.datatools.windowing.filter import LabelBalanceFilter

# We define a dict which give us the information about what standardization apply to each
# columns.
std_by_feautures = {
    "close": ClassicStd(),
    "return": ClassicStd(with_mean=False),  # to avoid to shift we don't center
    "adx": MinMaxStd(minmax=(0, 100))  # the value observed in the adx are between
                                       # 0 and 100 and we
                                       # want to set it between 0 and 1.
}
data_intervals = DataIntervals(data, n_intervals=10)
data_intervals.standardize(std_by_feautures)

# We can apply a filter the dataset we want. Here we will filter the values in order
# to balance the histogram of return value. For this, we use the label previously process
# on return.
filter_by_set = {
    "train": LabelBalanceFilter("label")  # the column we will balance the data is 'label
                                        # the max count will be automatically process
}

# dict_train_val_test is a dict with the key 'train', 'val', 'test'.
# The value of the dict is a  WTSeries (a windowed time series).
dict_train_val_test = data_intervals.windowing(
    window_width=30,
    window_step=1,
    selected_columns=["close", "return", "adx"],
    filter_by_dataset=filter_by_set,
    std_by_feature=None  # Here we can pass the same kind of dict previously introduce
                         # to apply the standardization independtly on each window
)
class mlcf.datatools.data_intervals.DataIntervals(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, n_intervals: int, prop_val_test: float = 0.2, prop_val: float = 0.3)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Data Intervals Class. It provides tools to divide a data frame into Nx3 parts and handles them.

raw_dataÔÉÅ

Raw time series data frame (unsplit).

Type

pandas.DataFrame

n_intervalsÔÉÅ

Number of intervals created after splitting the data frame.

Type

int

train_intervalsÔÉÅ

List of data frame corresponding to training set whose length is {n_intervals}

Type

List[pandas.DataFrame]

val_intervalsÔÉÅ

List of data frame corresponding to validation set whose length is {n_intervals}

Type

List[pandas.DataFrame]

test_intervalsÔÉÅ

List of data frame corresponding to test set whose length is {n_intervals}

Type

List[pandas.DataFrame]

intervalsÔÉÅ

(Dict[str, List[pandas.DataFrame]): A dictionary of keys ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô, ‚Äòtest‚Äô that groups 3 sets of intervals.

__call__(set_name: str) → List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]ÔÉÅ

It calls the get() function and returns its result.

Parameters

set_name (str) ‚Äì The string key corresponding to the desired set. It must be chosen between ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô, ‚Äòtest‚Äô.

Returns

The corresponding set.

The corresponding set.

List[pd.DataFrame]

__init__(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, n_intervals: int, prop_val_test: float = 0.2, prop_val: float = 0.3)ÔÉÅ

It creates a DataInterval object from a time series data frame.

The {data} will be split into {n_intervals}. Then these parts will be split into 3 sets such as ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô and ‚Äòtest‚Äô.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) ‚Äì The time series data frame on which the split operation will be performed.

  • n_intervals (int) ‚Äì The number of intervals to split the {data}.

  • prop_val_test (float, optional) ‚Äì The proportion of val and test rows. The proportion of train is equal to 1-{prop_val_test}. It is set to 0.2 by default.

  • prop_val (float, optional) ‚Äì The proportion of val set amoung the test set. The proportion of val rows is : {prop_val_test}*{prop_val}. The proportion of test part is : {prop_val_test}*(1-{prop_val}). It is set to 0.3 by default.

__iter__() → IteratorÔÉÅ

It iterates over the {self.intervals} dictionary.

Returns

The dictionary iterator

Return type

Dict

classmethod create_list_interval(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, n_intervals: int = 1) → List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]ÔÉÅ

It splits the {data} into {n_intervals} and returns the list of these intervals.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) ‚Äì The time series data frame.

  • n_intervals (int, optional) ‚Äì The number of intervals to split the data frame. Default to 1.

Raises

  • ValueError ‚Äì If the data frame is empty.

  • TypeError ‚Äì If {n_intervals} is not an Integer.

  • ValueError ‚Äì If the number of intervals is less than or equal to 0.

Returns

The list of data frame (intervals).

Return type

List[pd.DataFrame]

get(set_name: str) → List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]ÔÉÅ

Given a {set_name}, it returns the corresponding set (list of dataframe). The {set_name} string value must be ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô or ‚Äòtest‚Äô.

Parameters

set_name (str) ‚Äì The string key corresponds to the desired set. It must be chosen between ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô, ‚Äòtest‚Äô.

Raises

ValueError ‚Äì If the {set_name} does not match any set name in the self.intervals dictionnary.

Returns

The corresponding list of dataframe.

Return type

List[pd.DataFrame]

classmethod split_train_val_test(list_intervals: List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame], prop_val_test: float, prop_val: float = 0.0) → Tuple[List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame], List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame], List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]]ÔÉÅ

It splits each interval (data frame) of {list_intervals} in 3 sets: ‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô and ‚Äòtest‚Äô. The proportions of train, val and test sets are given by {prop_val_test} and {prop_val} parameters.

Parameters

  • list_intervals (List[pd.DataFrame]) ‚Äì A list of data frame.

  • prop_val_test (float) ‚Äì The proportion of val and test rows. The proportion of train is equal to 1-{prop_val_test}.

  • prop_val (float, optional) ‚Äì The proportion of val set amoung the test set. The proportion of val rows is : {prop_val_test}*{prop_val}. The proportion of test part is : {prop_val_test}*(1-{prop_val}). Default to 0.0.

Returns

A tuple of lists corresponding to the train, validation and test parts of the given list data frames.

Return type

Tuple[List[pd.DataFrame], List[pd.DataFrame], List[pd.DataFrame]]

standardize(std_by_feature: Dict[str, mlcf.datatools.standardisation.StandardisationModule]) → NoneÔÉÅ

An inplace operation applying a standardisation over all the data frame intervals of DataIntervals. Fit operation of the standardisation is performed only on the ‚Äòtrain‚Äô set. Transform operation of the standardisation is performed on every set.

Parameters

std_by_feature (Dict[str, StandardisationModule]) ‚Äì A dictionary prodiving the standardisation to be applied on each column. The dictionary format must be as following: {string -> StandardisationModule}. The key must correspond to a column name (a feature) of the data frame. The value is any object inheriting from the StandardisationModule class.

windowing(window_width: int, window_step: int = 1, selected_columns: Optional[List[str]] = None, filter_by_dataset: Optional[Dict[str, mlcf.windowing.filtering.filter.WindowFilter]] = None, std_by_feature: Optional[Dict[str, mlcf.datatools.standardisation.StandardisationModule]] = None) → Dict[str, mlcf.windowing.iterator.tseries.WTSeries]ÔÉÅ

It performs the windowing operation over all intervals producing for each set a WTSeries (a windowed time series). We can provide a dictionnary indicating the standardisation used for each feature. We can provide a dictionary indicating the window filtering operation applied to each set.

Parameters

  • window_width (int) ‚Äì The window width.

  • window_step (int, optional) ‚Äì The step between each window. Defaults to 1.

  • selected_columns (Optional[List[str]], optional) ‚Äì The list of names of the selected features. If None is given, then all features will be kept. The default value is None.

  • filter_by_dataset (Optional[Dict[str, WindowFilter]], optional) ‚Äì A dictionary that gives information about the type of window filtering applied on each set. The format of the dictionary is such as: {key (string) -> WindowFilter}. The key is the name of a set (‚Äòtrain‚Äô, ‚Äòval‚Äô and ‚Äòtest‚Äô). The value is any object inheriting from the WindowFilter class. If None is set then no window filtering is applied. The default value is None.

  • std_by_feature (Optional[Dict[str, StandardisationModule]], optional) ‚Äì A dictionary prodiving the standardisation to be applied on each column. Here, the standardisation is done independently on each window. The dictionary format must be as following: {string -> StandardisationModule}. The key must correspond to a column name (a feature) of the data frame. The value is any object inheriting from the StandardisationModule class.

Returns

A dictionnary such as {key (string) -> WTSeries } where the key correspond to a set name.

Return type

Dict[str, WTSeries]
